bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to Wickliffe Rose, August 29, 1922

div1.p: White writes that he has been mediating between Connor and Stubbs. He briefly describes the situation in Mexico regarding yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph H. White to Wickliffe Rose, August 29, 1922
div1.opener:
( C O P Y )
H. R. C
I. H. B.
White
COMPANIA TRANSCONTINENTAL DE PETROLEO, S.A.
TRANSCONTINENTAL PETROLEUM CO.
Apartado 657
Tampico, Tamps., Mexico.
Aug. 29, (1922)
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I got here yesterday and have been quite occupied settling the
unfortunate quarrel between Connor and Stubbs who took umbrage at Connor's
questioning his diagnosis (subsequently confirmed) and who was in very
militant mood but has now calmed down. Conditions are not satisfactory
to me in Tampico as the incidence of Stegomyiae has risen largely since
we turned it over to Cuaron and I really seriously disagree with Connor's
opinion that Cuaron has done well.

Indeed I am so far the other way that I have agreed to the ur-
gent request of the oil people to Cyanide the whole of Panuco in order
to terminate that outbreak at once and I may and probably will have to
advance a part of the $5000 estimated cost while the Consejo is trying
to get the money. Hence I will wire you to send Scannell more funds
as he only has about $3000+ turned over by Connor.

Please understand that I am not blaming Connor, but things
are so “warm” here against him that I sent him to Merida to re-organize
there and see that the new man, my old reliable clinician Diego Hernan-
dez, gets going in proper shape.

I really can't say that anyone is blameworthy in this matter,
as we all, Stubbs, Connor, Scannell, and I agree that what happened was
a stray case last fall into bandit country where none of us can go nor
have been, and then a gradual village to village infection month by
-2-
month till it reached Panuco probably in May or June and Monroe accep-
ted the Mex. Drs. statements that it was malaria only.

Take a line from Tuxpam, west for about 45 miles or less to
Alamo and then count all west and north for 100 miles as the territory
I mean and that will bring you to Tantoyuca, from which on north to
Panuco is reasonably civilized and, the dangerous, can be visited.

Now, I am going to temporarily switch to the primitive but
absolutely effective fumigation for Panuco to prevent a panic in that
and Tampico, and shall force down the incidence here to a safe point
at the earliest possible moment.

Scannell is doing well and will I think handle the situation
properly when I am away, but I shall come back frequently and stay here
quite the greater part of my time.
